title: Why can we analyze concentration gradients of single substances ignoring the electrical gradient? Can a molecule or ion 'recognize' another of its kind? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not in general. An electrical gradient can create a concentration gradient* if ions and counterions are allowed to migrate. The concentration gradient will cause diffusion of the charges that will oppose the electrical gradient. At some time* after turning on the electrical field an equilibrium between concentration and electrical gradients will establish itself. This is assuming that the ions will not react with the sources of the electrical gradient, eg. metal electrodes. There’s no special property of which I am aware that allows a molecule or ion to ‘recognize’ others, although high concentrations of an ion will create an electrical field among the ions that adds/subtracts from an external electric field. * - edited in revision.
Molecules and ions don’t recognize themselves or anything. We recognize them from their varying behaviors and interactions.
